nodes.bodyText: Does GSON maintain full method names or does it drop Java bean notation? I know in Jackson's case this would serialize as hotelName (possibly HotelName as I'm not completely certain about how it handles casing).

What you refer is the one without annotation on Method.
However, if we do not have annoatation, we cannot guarantee what we pass is the getter method with 'get' prefix. I don't think we need to check too much things here as validating whether it is the invoked getter is a huge cost.

This needs to take into account a few more common scenarios.

Fields marked as transient will be ignored for serialization. This is an expectation in Java that transient fields are never serialized.
Need to check whether the field is marked with GSON's Expose annotation. A common configuration in GSON is constructing a Gson with excludeFieldsWithoutExposeAnnotation which won't include those in serialization. Additionally, Expose could contain information on whether the field will ever be included in serialization with serialize = false.

FieldBuilder and Json serialization are different things. Private field might not able to serializable to jackson but it is serializable to FieldBuilder. If we want to utilize azure core, then azure core method cannot validate too many annotations, which blocks SDK to have its own use.
For FieldBuilder, customer has to use @FieldIgnore in Search SDK to ignore the field.
For method use, I don't have too much use case here, so what to return is an open issue. Suppose we have two getters, one with @JsonGetter and one without @JsonGetter. The getSerializerMemberName API did not know too much but the method you passed in, so we cannot make the logic too complicated in the API.
Javadoc copy and paste error?
Fixed.
Is this how Jackson serializes methods annotated with JsonProperty? Also, do we need to handle JsonGetter for methods?
@JsonGetter is to use for multiple getter cases. The method passed into the method doesn't include other method information. Let me know what case you want to support.
I believe we need to account for JsonIgnore.

We provide @FieldIgnore for FieldBuilder to ignore the field for SearchIndex, which provide the flexibility of decouple the use case of FieldBuilder and serialization (Document). The getSerializerMemberName is useful for FieldBuilder, customer can use serialize and deserialize API for document serialization.
I don't think we should suppress this warning.
Same comment about suppressing checkstyle:LineLength.

Don't remove these

tags, Javadocs doesn't retain text newlines as it is HTML. This without it the Javadocs will go from being: Sets the HTTP pipeline to use for the service client. If pipeline is set... to Sets the HTTP pipeline to use for the service client. If pipeline is set...
@srnagar, looks like this will require codegen changes.
This is a POC of whether Search can adopt the autorest chagnes. Will regen the code after autorest change get merged.
Could rename this to SerializedNameProvider, right now the interface sounds like it will serialize property names.

nodes.bodyText: Should update this error message since it was copied from JsonSerializerProviders.

I would have GsonJsonSerializer implement the PropertyNameSerializer interface. The reason we made them separate was for cases when a customer wants to just create a custom JsonSerializer implementation they aren't strictly required to implement PropertyNameSerializer as well (though it would be recommended for completeness).

I will remove the seperate Jackson/GsonPropertyNameSerializer and merge it into Jackson/GsonJsonSerializer.
Meanwhile, I will make up the getSerialziedMemberName to read Class and Constructor as well.

Verified Gson is not able to rename property on getter.
If we have GsonJsonSerializer implement the PropertyNameSerializer interface we won't need this class, which feels very duplicative of GsonJsonSerializerBuilder.

nodes.bodyText: Would love to see some integration tests to go along with these unit tests. Cases where we pass a class into the PropertyNameSerializer and also serialize the same class into a JsonElement where we then validate that the JsonElement contains JSON attributes with the names returned by PropertyNameSerializer.
This can be removed as TypeReference<T> has been merged into Azure Core Experimental.

.copy() the serializer otherwise this will mutate the Azure Core serializer which we won't want. Another option would be creating a new instance of JacksonAdapter rather than use createDefaultSerializerAdapter (which creates or returns the global instance depending on whether it has already been instantiated).

Is there an API for .copy()?
The API here is to use across the rest client(core serializer). I would like to share cross the clients to save the initialization time as they always use the same settings.
For the customer serializer layer, we have a new instance to make sure core serializer doesn't mix the use with it.

There is an issue with changing this for all clients as this could affect how AppConfiguration, KeyVault, Storage, etc serialize and deserialize when used along side Search which mutates the global serializer. Maybe this method should be turned into a lazy loaded which initializes a constant ObjectMapper used for Search instead of changing the global ObjectMapper.
May need to comment this out again as I don't think PointGeometry will be released this month.
Any reason we can't support CharSequence by using its toString method which returns its value as a String? I believe Jackson and GSON will handle CharSequence similar to a String.
Yes, I think this one can move to the supported type mapping if we all agree to it.
Moved to Supported search date type mapper

Would we be allowed to upcast these types into Double and Integer respectively? Possible the same with Byte and byte to Integer?
Or is the idea being more restrictive is safer?

There is no hard requirement on this currently.
Here is the reason why we restrict more types now:

Adding more to allowlist is allowed for the release, but taking back is kind of breaking changes. I prefer to make it as limited as possible to minimize breaking changes we might introduce.
Mapping byte to integer is not quite right when serialize model POJO to Json. SearchField will use EDM.Integer, but upload doc would have it transfer to encoded string when send to the wire. It is really hard to predict how customer handle it. It is better to block it unitl we have clear use case.
Could we call this method getSearchFields? build feels analogous to a builder pattern.
Then the API is different than .NET.
This should only require. transitive is when it is used as part of the public API.
Why is the SPI provider being removed?

nodes.bodyText: Search needs to requires transitive com.azure.core since it contains Azure Core types in the public API.
It is transitive from azure.core.serializer.json.jackson
Then azure.core.serializer.json.jackson must be made transitive.

I'm wondering if the SPI providers should be different but return the same type, basically copying this class but only having it implement PropertyNameSerializerProvider.
Should return null if Member is either a Constructor or Executable.

Talked offline.
We currently use the API to deal with the Field/Method which contains Jackson/Gson etc rename annotations. Will return null for all other subclasses of Member (except Field).
This won't be how Jackson default handles a JsonProperty annotated method, it'll attempt to remove the Java bean prefix of get or is.

Jackson can serialize property name invoked getter even it is not in a format of get{PropertyName}.
JavaBeans has limitation on reading this.
In order to achieve what Jackson does, we have to introduce a really complicated logic in core, which also bring the risk in core. Talked offline, we can leave the function in future release, also we can have the logic inside of client SDK library first.
Same comment about returning null if member is a Constructor or Executable.

nodes.bodyText: Did we ever determine whether GSON uses Methods during serialization?

From what we determined yesterday, we need to return null here. Will fix it.
We only deal with the member which can be renamed through annotation.

Let's make this a static somewhere instead of instantiating a new instance every time we are deserializing. I believe TypeReference<Map<String, Object>> is used in a few places so let's make it a constant somewhere in implementation.
Will place it into impl Utility.
This should use JsonSerializerProviders.createInstance(), if azure-core-serializer-json-jackson is excluded this will fail to compile.
Sure. Will change to MemberNameConverterProviders.createInstance()

The method is to use when customer does not  pass us JsonSerializer.
We have to use JsonSerializer API  for workflow. If return JacksonAdapter, this is how we hook up with JsonSerializer. Only JacksonJsonSerializerBuilder provide a way to take ObjectMapper.
Talked offline. We will use search specific JacksonAdapter as a default serializer if customer do not pass any serializer in.

Do we want this to be MemberNameConverter or JsonSerializer? .NET is using ObjectSerializer as a parameter to FieldBuilder.
cc: @heaths @tg-msft @srnagar @JonathanGiles
.NET also proposed to use the option class. The options class is a placeholder which can put more properties in future.

I think @alzimmermsft was referring to using JsonSerialier or MemberNameConverter. Using the options class is okay, we should align on what the options will contain - serializer or member name converter?
Both JsonSerializer and ObjectSerializer miss the API of convertMemberName, which is the necessary one using in FieldBuilder.
I don't think this matches what the FieldBuilder API allows, that checks if the serializer is null and uses a default implementation.
There is no necessary to use the API if no serializer to pass. They can simply pass new FieldBuilderOptions(). It is lazy initialization at the time we call static API
I'm wrong, it checked if this type was null, not this property.

Not a huge fan of this being an asynchronous return and we have prior art which has non-service APIs returning synchronously in an asynchronous client. getSearchAsyncClient on this client is synchronous, I think this should be made synchronous as well.
@srnagar @JonathanGiles, let me know if you disagree.
I can have synchronous call. Is it necessary to have the function in both sync and async client?
For convenience I would say yes.
This should be named  CANNOT_FIND_MEMBER_NAME_CONVERTER_PROVIDER.
